title: American Psychological Association: subjects and participants
content:
According to the newly published [sixth edition of APA publication manual](http://web.archive.org/web/20090923203227/http:/www.apastyle.org/) (p 73), people who participate in an experiment are no longer referred to solely as participants. They can now referred to as participants _and_ subjects. Originally, people were referred to as subjects, and at some point the term participant was adopted and the term subject was reserved for animals (I’m not a historian).

It’s nice that we are “allowed” to use the term subjects again as it is consistent with the long standing acronym Ss.
author: Christopher Dean

comments.content: I don’t think the term _participants_ has ever caught on in mainstream psychology. I believe the term came from the applied field of user centered design, where the people brought in for lab studies are viewed as participants in the design process.
